subsection.title: Repeated Eigenvalues
subsection.p: A more interesting case occurs if A = \begin{pmatrix} \lambda & 1 \\ 0 & \lambda \end{pmatrix}. Again, both eigenvalues are \lambda; however, there is only one linearly independent eigenvector, which we can take to be (1, 0). Therefore, we have a single straight-line solution {\mathbf x}_1(t) = \alpha e^{\lambda t}\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}.

To find other solutions, we will rewrite the system as
x' & = \lambda x + y y' & = \lambda y.
This is a partially coupled system. If y \neq 0, the solution of the second equation is y(t) = \beta e^{\lambda t}. Therefore, the first equation becomes x' = \lambda x + \beta e^{\lambda t}, which is a first-order linear differential equation with solution x(t) = \alpha e^{\lambda t} + \beta t e^{\lambda t}. Consequently, a solution to our system is \alpha e^{\lambda t} \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} + \beta e^{\lambda t} \begin{pmatrix} t \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}.

example.p:
Consider the linear system
x' \amp = -x + y y' \amp = -y x(0) \amp = 1 y(0) \amp = 3.
The matrix that corresponds to this system is A = \begin{pmatrix} -1 & 1 \\ 0 & -1 \end{pmatrix} has a single eigenvalue, \lambda = -1. An eigenvector for \lambda is \mathbf v = (1, 0). Thus, the general solution to our system is
x(t) \amp = c_1 e^{-t} + c_2 t e^{-t} y(t) \amp = c_2 e^{-t}.
Applying the initial conditions x(0) = 1 and y(0) = 3, the solution to our initial value problem is
x(t) \amp = e^{-t} + 3te^{-t} y(t) \amp = 3e^{-t}.
Notice that we have only one straightline solution ().

subsection.title: Solving Systems with Repeated Eigenvalues
subsection.p: If the characteristic equation has only a single repeated root, there is a single eigenvalue. If this is the situation, then we actually have two separate cases to examine, depending on whether or not we can find two linearly independent eigenvectors.

example.p:
Suppose we have the system \mathbf x' = A \mathbf x, where A = \begin{pmatrix} 2 & 0 \\ 0 & 2 \end{pmatrix}. The single eigenvalue is \lambda = 2, but there are two linearly independent eigenvectors, \mathbf v_1 = (1,0) and \mathbf v_2 = (0,1). In this case our solution is \mathbf x(t) = c_1 e^{2t} \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} + c_2 e^{2t} \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}. This is not too surprising since the system
x' & = 2x y' & = 2y
is uncoupled and each equation can be solved separately.

Now let us consider the example \mathbf x' = A \mathbf x, where A = \begin{pmatrix} 5 & 1 \\ -4 & 1 \end{pmatrix}. Since the characteristic polynomial of A is \lambda^2 - 6 \lambda + 9 = (\lambda - 3)^2, we have only a single eigenvalue \lambda = 3 with eigenvector \mathbf v_1 = (1, -2). This gives us one solution to our system, \mathbf x_1(t) = e^{3t}\mathbf v_1; however, we still need a second solution.

subsection.p: If the eigenvalue is positive, we will have a nodal source. If it is negative, we will have a nodal sink. Notice that we have only given a recipe for finding a solution to \mathbf x' = A \mathbf x, where A has a repeated eigenvalue and any two eigenvectors are linearly dependent. We will justify our procedure in the next section ().
